results.title: Kalee Indomitable Model 8 Front Shutter Projector
results.brief_description:
Manufactured in Leeds, England by A.Kershaw & Son, and brought into Australia prior to the introduction of ‘the talkies’. Complete with Trutrim lamp house.
1 of 2: Projector and Lens
2 0f 2: Lamphouse

results.title: Horn used by Norman Spencer
results.brief_description: Long, thin horn with electrically powered motor, used on the TV program “In Melbourne Tonight”, by Norman Spencer as an early form of television censorship

results.title: Homicide small display case
results.material_description:
001: Rabbit fur felt with a ribbon band, feather trim, satin lining and plastic.
002: Black plastic radio and spiral cord.  Metal socket/plug.
003: Lightweight metal replica handcuffs.  There is no key to lock or unlock them.
004: Silver-coloured metal van with metal wheels.
005: Paper
006: black and white photo housed behind glass in a wooden frame which has been painted green and gold.
007: black and white photograph
008: black and white photograph
results.brief_description: Homicide TV series: TV Week cover, handcuffs, detective’s Akubra hat, cast photos and period telephone (Citizen Band radio), and a toy police van.

results.title: Home made 35mm Film Projector
results.brief_description:
True example of Australian ingenuity - spool arms made from bicycle pedal shanks. But it worked, and was the main component of an early days home cinema.
1 of 2: Projector
2 of 2: Box of memorabilia (4 x Cinema tickets / 1 x ‘Operation newsreel’ sticker / 1 x ‘Hoyts’ badge / 1 x ‘Last Film Search’ badge / 1 x ‘On Our Selection’ postcard / 1 x Glass slide advertisement / 1 x ‘Pathe’ small 35mm can of something / 1 x empty 35mm 50’ can of ‘Fox Movietone News’ / 1 x ‘Kodak’ roll of photographic film / 1 x ‘Build your own projector’ book / 1 x ‘Material for Radio Electrical and Mechanical’ catalogue / 1 x ‘Sun News Pictorial Hobby Book’ / 1 x ‘Liberty Theatre’ advertisment mounted on cardboard)
